channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Jeremy Hunt to confirm national living wage to rise to £11 an hour
item.description: The move will affect two million of the lowest-paid workers, the chancellor will tell the Tory conference.

item.title: 72-hour doctor strike to cause extreme disruption
item.description: Three-day joint walkout by junior doctors and consultants begins on Monday as pay dispute escalates.

item.title: Water companies want £156 bill rise to fund upgrades
item.description: The industry says it needs the cash to fund £96bn of investment to cut sewage spills and build reservoirs.

item.title: Gillian Keegan pledges crackdown on mobiles in schools
item.description: Heads in England will be issued guidance aimed at stopping pupils using phones during the school day.

item.title: Live Aid concert to be turned into stage musical
item.description: The show at London's Old Vic Theatre will feature songs which were played on the day of the concert.

item.title: Gabon's predators on the pitch: Inside a paedophile football scandal
item.description: BBC Africa Eye speaks to more than 30 witnesses about a network of abuse that continued for decades.

item.title: Turkey strikes Kurdish rebels after Ankara blast
item.description: Turkey conducts air strikes in northern Iraq, hours after a suicide blast hit the interior ministry in Ankara.

item.title: Covid will 'continue to surprise us', warns health official
item.description: Health officials are encouraging anyone eligible to get jabs to protect against Covid and flu.

item.title: Bradley Lowery: Man charged over 'taunt' at Sheffield Wednesday match
item.description: Dale Houghton, 31, from Rotherham, will appear in court on Monday and faces a football banning order.

item.title: First class stamp price rises to £1.25
item.description: The price rise comes as Royal Mail seeks to cover higher delivery costs while letter numbers fall.

item.title: Tottenham 2-1 Liverpool: 'VAR error undermined sporting integrity' - Reds
item.description: Liverpool have released a statement saying VAR's error in the defeat to Tottenham has undermined sporting integrity.

item.title: Graham Linehan attacks cancel culture at Conservative conference fringe event
item.description: The comedy writer tells a free speech debate his views on gender have made it hard to find places to speak.

item.title: Las Vegas Sphere: Look inside the new venue for the first time
item.description: Rock band U2 headline the new ball-shaped venue as it finally opens its doors to the public.

item.title: The Papers: 'Tories eye PM's throne' and 'Schools phones ban'
item.description: Policy announcements and political intrigue emanating from the Tory conference dominate Monday's papers.

item.title: Migrants trying to reach the UK cross the Alps on foot
item.description: More than 130,000 migrants have entered Italy this year. Many try to head further into Europe.

item.title: The former footballer scoring with his art
item.description: Craig Black has been to the World Cup not because of his football talents, but because of his art.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it investigating and how does it work?
item.description: The second round of public hearings examining the UK's handling of the pandemic starts on 3 October.

item.title: The people going 'monk mode' to limit social media use
item.description: A growing number of individuals are using apps to block access to social media and the internet.

item.title: Taylor Swift attends Travis Kelce's NFL game with Ryan Reynolds, Blake lively and Hugh Jackman
item.description: A-listers Ryan Reynolds, Blake lively and Hugh Jackman joined the singer at her rumoured beau's game.

item.title: From Scotland to Canada, a totem pole finally returns home
item.description: The artefact was stolen from an indigenous community in Canada. This is the story of its homecoming.

item.title: Katherine Ryan: Difficult choice to work with dangerous comic
item.description: Comedian Katherine Ryan tells Radio 4 it was a difficult decision to work with a man she considered "dangerous".

item.title: Jake Abraham: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels actor dies aged 56
item.description: The actor was best known for his roles in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and Channel 4 drama GBH.

item.title: M53 bus crash student was warm-hearted and wonderful, family says
item.description: Jessica Baker, 15, and driver Stephen Shrimpton died when the school coach overturned.

item.title: Dame Helen Mirren speaks of 'delicate balance' in playing Golda Meir
item.description: The Oscar-winning actor has faced criticism for playing Israel's first female PM Golda Meir in a new film.

item.title: Croydon: Community remembers 'amazing' Elianne Andam
item.description: About 350 people gathered on Sunday to remember the 15-year-old schoolgirl who was fatally stabbed.

item.title: Rouen fire: Major fire breaks out in French city
item.description: A huge fire tears through two disused buildings in the French city, with flames and smoke rising high into the sky.

item.title: Vivienne Westwood's own wardrobe raided to be used in Paris catwalk show
item.description: Vivienne Westwood's widower chose clothes she wore and made over 30 years for the brand's new collection.

item.title: Iceland boss quits Tories labelling party 'out of touch'
item.description: Richard Walker had tried to become a Tory MP but has quit the party on the eve of the annual conference.

item.title: Last supermoon of the year captured on camera
item.description: Space enthusiast in Kathmandu, Nepal and the US state of Colorado filmed the spectacle.

item.title: Winter warning as new energy price cap comes in
item.description: The annual energy bill for a typical household falls on Sunday but is high by historical standards.

item.title: Ban on single-use plastic cutlery comes into force in England
item.description: Polystyrene cups and balloon sticks are also banned in England as part of efforts to cut waste.

item.title: Brexit: NI secretary believes unionist concerns can be addressed
item.description: Chris Heaton-Harris addresses unionist concerns as a new system for post-Brexit trade is implemented.

item.title: Glastonbury Festival 2024 tickets rise to £360
item.description: The South West event is considerably more expensive than other festivals that have released prices.

item.title: Bradley Lowery: Two held over 'taunts' aimed at Sunderland fans
item.description: South Yorkshire Police say the arrests are part of its investigation into alleged public order offences.

item.title: Enfield: First baby beaver born in London in 400 years
item.description: Enfield council launched reintroduction programme in 2022 to bring beavers back to the capital.

item.title: Billy Connolly had 'serious falls' after balance issues, says wife
item.description: The comedian's wife says the issues are the "most significant" symptom of his Parkinson's disease.

item.title: Jody Cundy: Learning Strictly Come Dancing routines is taxing
item.description: Jody Cundy says the "mental part" of dancing was "getting me".

item.title: 'Outstanding' prostate cancer trial could change radiotherapy
item.description: Experts say the findings could lead to "enormous change" in the way the treatment is delivered.

item.title: Motorist fined after dog seen behind wheel of car
item.description: Police in Slovakia have fined a man after a dog was pictured in the driving seat of his Skoda.

item.title: Driver caught drinking mug of tea on motorway
item.description: A tea-drinking motorist is fined £100 after being caught on camera driving on the M6 in Cheshire last year.

item.title: US urges Serbia to withdraw troops from Kosovo border as tensions rise
item.description: In response to the "current situation", the UK sends troops to join Nato peacekeepers Kfor in Kosovo.

item.title: Train strikes set to cause travel disruption
item.description: Aslef union members are walking out in a long-running dispute over pay and conditions.

item.title: Week in pictures: 23-29 September 2023
item.description: A selection of striking images from around the world, taken over the past seven days.

item.title: Evergrande: The rise and fall of the property giant's billionaire founder
item.description: Hui Ka Yan, the founder of a crisis-hit Chinese property giant, is under police surveillance.

item.title: British baked beans become reality after successful Lincolnshire harvest
item.description: Scientists have successfully adapted the haricot variety so it can be grown in British soil.

item.title: Sycamore Gap: 'We are devastated - it's so sad to see the tree gone'
item.description: Members of the public have been sharing memories of the 300-year-old tree in Northumberland, after it was cut down this week.

item.title: Ask, Don't Assume: Disability Rights UK deletes ‘misjudged’ post on ads
item.description: Disability Rights UK deletes a post which accused the government of "murderous ableist policies".

item.title: Hijabs allowed in athletes' village at Paris 2024 - IOC
item.description: The IOC say hijabs will be allowed inside the athletes' village at next year's Olympics, despite hosts France banning their team members from wearing them.

item.title: Aston Villa women to wear sweat-heavy shirts despite talks with manufacturer Castore
item.description: Aston Villa boss says her players have concerns over the club's shirts but will have to wear them for their WSL opener against Manchester United on Sunday.

item.title: Woman in £37,000 payout after boss dismissed menopause 'excuses'
item.description: Karen Farquharson, 49, was told to "get on with it" after being off work ill due to her symptoms.

item.title: Lizzo asks judge to dismiss dancers' harassment allegations
item.description: The US singer has lodged her first legal response against harassment claims made by her ex-dancers.

item.title: Nottingham University Hospitals Trust failed to send 400,000 letters
item.description: A former employee told the BBC there was a lack of responsibility over a new computer system.

item.title: Ryder Cup 2023: Europe's players want Luke Donald as captain for 2025 in United States
item.description: Europe's players want Luke Donald to remain their Ryder Cup captain after regaining Ryder Cup with a 16½-11½ victory over the United States in Rome.

item.title: Rangers: Michael Beale sacked as manager; Steven Davis takes interim charge
item.description: Michael Beale has been sacked as Rangers manager after slipping seven points behind Celtic after seven games of the season.

item.title: Ryder Cup 2023: Key moments as Europe regain trophy in Rome
item.description: Watch key moments as Europe regain the Ryder Cup with victory over the United States in Rome.

item.title: Arsenal 0-1 Liverpool: Miri Taylor scores winner in Women's Super League shock
item.description: Miri Taylor's second-half strike gives Liverpool a surprise 1-0 Women's Super League win at Arsenal in front of 54,115 fans.

item.title: Ryder Cup: Rory McIlroy says Joe LaCava row fired up Europe's victory charge
item.description: Rory McIlroy says Europe were given "extra fire in their bellies" to seal Ryder Cup victory by the "disrespect" shown by American caddie Joe LaCava.

item.title: Simone Biles: American lands historic vault on World Championships return in Antwerp
item.description: Simone Biles becomes the first woman to execute a Yurchenko double pike vault on her return to the World Gymnastics Championships in Antwerp.

item.title: Steve Cooper's culture means Nottingham Forest won't struggle again - Jermaine Jenas analysis
item.description: Jermaine Jenas feels Nottingham Forest are still a work in progress under Steve Cooper but he is convinced they will stay clear of the relegation battle.

item.title: What is happening to house prices, and could there be a crash?
item.description: How higher interest rates are changing the UK's housing market.

item.title: Mortgages: What happens if I am struggling to pay?
item.description: Many homeowners are worried about higher mortgage costs, but lenders must help those struggling.

item.title: First time home buyers: How much can I borrow?
item.description: With rents rising, more people are crunching the numbers to see if they can afford to buy.

item.title: Train strikes: What days in September and October will rail travel be disrupted?
item.description: Train drivers are set to strike again, and London Underground staff are also taking action.

item.title: How to get a job: Six expert tips for finding work
item.description: There are 10m people out of work in the UK, so if you're searching for a job you're not alone. Here are some tips on how to get started.

item.title: Energy price cap: What is it and will bills continue to go down?
item.description: The price cap which sets typical annual household energy bills is falling slightly from October.

item.title: Energy bills: What can I do if I can't afford to pay?
item.description: If you're struggling to afford your gas and electricity bills, what options are available?

item.title: Energy saving tips: Five ways to cut costs this winter
item.description: Energy prices will be lower this coming winter - but you may be able to save even more on your bill.

item.title: Rent increases: What you can do about a rise from your landlord
item.description: The BBC's Lora Jones tells you four things you can do, if your landlord asks for more money.

item.title: Interest rates: How the Bank of England's decision affects you and your money
item.description: The Bank of England has held interest rates at 5.25%, bringing a run of 14 consecutive rises to an end.

item.title: Five ways to save money on your packed lunch
item.description: Grabbing food on the go can be expensive so here are some top tips on making savings at lunchtime.

item.title: Food prices: How can I save money on my grocery shop?
item.description: The cost-of-living crisis continues to bite. Here are some things that can reduce the impact.

item.title: What is GDP and how is it measured?
item.description: A basic guide to how the economy is measured and why that calculation matters.

item.title: What is the UK inflation rate and why is it so high?
item.description: The rate at which prices are rising has fallen but remains well above the 2% inflation target.

item.title: Debt: What should I pay first and what can I do?
item.description: What help and options are available to people struggling with debt repayments?

item.title: How to save money even when the budget is tight
item.description: The interest paid on savings is better than anything seen for years, so how can you save when bills are rising?

item.title: Rent prices: How much have they gone up in your area?
item.description: Use our interactive tool to find out what the average rent is in your area.

item.title: Cost-of-living payments: Who is getting them and when?
item.description: Low-income households, pensioners and some disabled people will get extra help with energy bills.

item.title: Cost of living: Five tips when asking for a pay rise
item.description: Recruiters, a manager and a workplace psychologist give their advice on how to negotiate for more money.

item.title: Renting: What are your rights as a tenant?
item.description: With one in five people now renting in the UK, it's important to understand your rights as a tenant.
